content:
TrackingExtract Class

Definition

The abstract base class representing a field or a property to be extracted from a workflow instance and its associated annotations.

In this Article

[System.Obsolete("The System.Workflow.* types are deprecated.  Instead, please use the new types from System.Activities.*")]
public abstract class TrackingExtract
Inheritance
System.Object
TrackingExtract

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
Equals(Object,Object)
GetHashCode()
GetType()
MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
ToString()

Remarks

Note

This material discusses types and namespaces that are obsolete. For more information, see Deprecated Types in Windows Workflow Foundation 4.5.

TrackingExtract is the abstract base class from which the ActivityDataTrackingExtract class and the WorkflowDataTrackingExtract class are derived. An ActivityDataTrackingExtract specifies a field or a property to be extracted from the activity associated with a tracking event and a WorkflowDataTrackingExtract specifies a field or a property to be extracted from the root activity of the workflow instance.

Constructors

TrackingExtract()

When implemented in a derived class, initializes a new instance of the TrackingExtract class.

protected TrackingExtract ();

Properties

Annotations

When implemented in a derived class, gets the annotations associated with the extracted data.

public abstract System.Workflow.Runtime.Tracking.TrackingAnnotationCollection Annotations { get; }
Value
TrackingAnnotationCollection

The TrackingAnnotationCollection associated with the extracted data.

Remarks

Annotations are strings that you define that contain information to associate with the extracted data.

Member

When implemented in a derived class, gets or sets the name of the field or property to be extracted.

public abstract string Member { get; set; }
Value
String

The dot delineated name of a field or a property.

Remarks

Member can be set to specify a field or a property; a member of a field or a property; or a single element of a field or a property (or a member of either) that implements the IEnumerable interface. For example, a single element in an array may be specified.
